title: When is the vote on Boris Johnson’s new Brexit deal?
text:
Brexit; what now? (Picture: Reuters/PA)

Ah, Brexit – in the wise words of ABBA, here we go again.

After Boris Johnson’s latest plan was delayed – again – on Saturday 19 October, what’s the next steps for Britain and the EU?

When is the next Brexit vote?

Leader of the House, Jacob Rees-Mogg, announced that the government will bring a vote on the new Brexit deal on Monday.

But – and it’s a big one – this can only be done after Speaker of the House John Bercow rules on whether he’ll allow another vote then.

File under: Pictures you can hear. ‘Orrrrddduuuhhhh’ (Pictures: Reuters)

What’s next with Brexit?

After the Letwin amendment passed, the government pulled the Brexit-deal vote expected to follow.

Boris Johnson was made to request a delay from the EU – which he did so with three letters not signed by him, in a move that might see him in contempt of parliament.

Advertisement

Advertisement

The opposition now have the opportunity to attach amendments to his deal, amendments that could halt Johnson’s plans.

Among them could be the possibility of a second referendum, or to force the prime minister to push for the UK’s continued membership in the EU customs union under a new trade deal.

Hundreds of thousands took to the streets to demand a People’s Vote as MPs debated this weekend (Picture: AFP/Getty Images)

But Michael Gove is insisting Britain will still leave on 31 October regardless.

Ambassadors in Europe plan to meet today, Sunday October 20, to discuss the latest updates

All 27 EU nations have to agree to an extension, and don’t have to give an immediate answer.

If the EU refuses a delay to Brexit, then Parliament has until 31 October to pass a deal and all associated legislation.

So, three years later, three prime ministers later, several meaningful votes later, Brexit is pretty much in the same condition as it was in 2016.

description: The latest with Brexit requires Boris Johnson to request an extension from the EU. MPs will vote again on Boris' proposed deal, but when?
